statement:
Let $U\subset\mathbb{C}$ be a domain, $a\in U$, and let
$f:U\setminus\{a\}$ be holomorphic. Then $a$ is a removable singularity
of $f$ if and only if $$\lim_{z\to a}(z-a)f(z)=0.$$

In particular, $a$ is a removable singularity of $f$ if $f$ is near $a$,
i.e. if there is a punctured neighborhood $V$ of $a$ and a real number
$M>0$ such that $|f(z)|<M$ for all $z\in V$.
